so that we may dwell in paradise wherever we please!

How excellent is the reward of those who work righteousness!”

39.75 And you shall see the angels going in procession around the throne,

celebrating the praises of their Lady of Light;

and judgment has been given that day to everyone with truth;

and all souls, the believers and the purified ones, will now say,

“All praises be to Goddess, the Lady of all Creatures!”

BOOK FORTY – ENTITLED THE TRUE BELIEVER

 

REVEALED AT MECCA

 

In the name of the most Merciful Goddess.

40.1  H.M.[124]

40.2 The revelation of this Books is from the Almighty, the Wise Goddess;

40.3 She is the forgiver of sins and the acceptor of your repentance;

She is swift to love you all; She understands your long suffering.

There is no Goddess but She; and before Her all souls will assemble together at the final resurrection.

40.4 For no soul disputes against the signs and miracles of Goddess,

except the unbelievers; but do not let their prosperity in the land deceive you with vain allurement.

40.5 The people of Nora, and the wicked ones that spewed hate and violence in the land,

accused their prophetesses of lying;

and each nation hatches evil plots against Goddess and their prophetesses,

that they might be able to get them under their power and subjection;

and they dispute with vain reasoning, and attempt to invalidate Truth;

therefore, their efforts are fruitless and nullified in the end.

40.6 This is the love and discipline that the Lady of Light sends you all;

and the unbelievers shall have great soul grief on the day of their resurrection.

40.7 The angels who bear up the throne of Goddess, and those who stand around it,[125]

celebrate the praise of the Lady of Light, and they believe in Her;

and they ask pardon and mercy for the true believers, saying,

“O Lady of Light, You encompass everything with Your mercy and knowledge;

therefore forgive those who repent, and follow Your path,

and deliver them from grief on the day of their resurrection;”

40.8 “O Lady of Light, lead them also into gardens of eternal abode,

which you have promised them, and to everyone who does right,

and to their mothers and their husbands, and their children; for You are the Almighty, the Wise Goddess.”

40.9 “And deliver them from evil on that day,

from Her who shows mercy, and this will be a great salvation to them.”

[28]“Virginity” is not used here because in the time of Yeshua, it meant only a woman that had not yet born a living child, and it did not mean a woman that was chaste.  A childless woman was not as treasured as a woman who had born a child.  A couple was not permitted to marry generally until the woman was either pregnant or had born a child.  An engaged couple lived together after an engagement ceremony.  If the woman did not become pregnant after a period of time, generally about a year, the union was dissolved by consent of the parties and both were free to become engaged again.  Marriages were only for those couples that were either pregnant or had born a child.  Hence, during Mary’s time, all first born children were technically born of a “virgin,” as the term was understood at the time.  In many societies, a woman became pregnant first, and then the marriage was performed.

[81]This is the story of a woman who had a husband that was quite handsome.  When the prophetess visited the home of her friend, she immediately fell in love with the man, whereupon the woman decided to divorce her husband so that the prophetess could marry him.  However, because the prophetess had “adopted” one of their children, under old Arab law, the marriage was forbidden.  In this passage, however, the prophetess makes it clear that the prohibitions on marrying close relatives do not extend to adopted family members.  Nonetheless, marrying the husband of a follower is not permitted, even of a prophetess, because it would undermine any pious mission.

[82]Various stories surround the interpretation of this passage.  Some say that Miriam was a hermaphrodite, or a leper, or had a rupture (hernia) and was deformed under her clothes, because she would wash in front of no one.  So to prove the gossip mongers wrong, someone stole her clothes while she was bathing, so she was forced to return home naked so the people could see there was nothing wrong with her.  Others suppose this was the false accusation of murder regarding her, or it could have been false suspicion of the murder of her sister Alana, who was on Mt. Hor when she died, but it is said the angels brought the body down with no marks, showing the people there was no murder, or some say Alana was brought back to life so she could tell the others that she was not murdered when she died.

[83]Various stories surround this passage as well.  Some say that the mountains, heaven and earth were actual entities endued with thought and that after they refused to worship Goddess, she removed their ability to think. 

[84]Such as plants, metals, animals, etc.

[85]Such as angels, Scripture, Goddess decrees, rain, thunder, lightening, etc.

[86]As the angels, the works of women, vapors, smoke, etc.

[87]There is controversy surrounding the making of statuary, and some say these were statutes which were permitted special to Denise, others say that they were not statutes so much as two lions and two eagles, so that when Denise mounted the throne, the lions stretched out their paws, and when she sat down the eagles shaded her with their wings.

[88]Being so large that 1,000 people could eat from them.

[89]It is said the cauldrons were so large that no one could move them and they had to be accessed by steps.

[90]The story is that Denise laid the foundation of the temple in Jerusalem, which was to be in lieu of the tabernacle of Miriam, which, when she died was to be finished by her daughter Salome.  But Salome died before the project was finished, but none of the genii workers knew because she died standing up in prayer, leaning on her staff, and so they continued to work, until one day a worm chewed through the staff of the dead Salome, causing her to fall down, and the genii to discover she was nothing but a corpse.  On that day the temple was finished.  It is said the genii used magic to complete the temple, and neither a hammer, nor an axe or any tool of iron was heard in the place were the genii worked.

[91]This is a bush that has no fruit and grows in brackish and barren ground.

[92]The lote tree is also known as the nettle tree and has small cherry like fruit and hard wood.

[93]Meaning “of Mary, mother of Yeshua.”  In this case it is believed that Arama was the name for a large holding pond that fed irrigation means for the gardens.

[94]Because they were greedy, a greater distance would have obliged the poor more towards the traveler, as in letting out their cattle further, and furnishing travelers with provisions, and so most of the cities between Saba and Syria were hence abandoned because they were no longer blessed.

[96]The Arabs believed that some angels have more wings than others, according to their species.  Gabrielle is said to have appeared before the prophetess with no less than 600 wings!

thence called the mansions or houses of the moon.

[105]In the Mideast, fire can be made by rubbing together two pieces of wood, one of the Markh tree, and the other of the Afar tree, and it will succeed even though the wood is green and wet.

[106]Some other interpretations: “the souls who range themselves in obedience to the law of Goddess and put away all infidelities,” or “the souls of those who rank themselves in battle array to fight nonviolently for the true religion, and they pursue on horses to distribute the word of the Korana, help the poor and the sick,” etc.

[107]Or “those who drive away the clouds,” or those “who put in motion all bodies, in the upper and lower world, according to divine command,” or “those who keep women from disobedience to Goddess by inspiring them with good thoughts and inclinations,” or “who drive away devils from them,” etc.

[108]It is believed that the perfect color for beautiful skin is the same pale color of an ostrich’s egg.

[111] The letter Sad, or Allat is the truthful.

[112]Either their previous religions, or the religion of Yeshua all of which came before the prophetess.

[113]It is said that Pharaoh used to tie his victims down to 4 stakes and then torture them.

[114]It is said that the two people were angels, and they came to Denise to test her.  So they simply ascended into her upper apartments when she did not expect anyone, i.e., during a nap or other private time during the day.

[115]Because Denise had taken the husband of Uriah, and ordered the wife to go to a dangerous place, where she was killed.

[116]These passages refer to the fact that Denise received one thousand beautiful well trained horses from a neighboring queendom, which were so beautiful, that she played with them several days before remembering her prayers and devotions.  Consequently, when she remembered, she begged forgiveness of Goddess, and vowed to give away all but a few horses to the poor, which she did immediately.

[117]This is referring to a story where Salome had a son who adored her; she was his favorite.  But he was sent away to govern over another distant part of the queendom.  While he was there, he lamented his mother’s absence so very much that he made a statute of her and began to worship it and talk to it, believing the statute talked back.  When Salome found out, she took the statute away, and placed it in a public area as a work of art, so he could no longer worship it.  While Salome was away, she had a special signet ring establishing her right to rule.  However, one of her favorite husbands would use it while she was away to rule for her.  One time, an evil person in disguise as Salome came up to the husband, and requested the ring back, which he obliged.  The false Salome ruled greedily, doing great injury to her people.  When the real Salome returned to her queendom, she was forced to become a beggar, walking the streets, until after 40 days, the imposter left the town and dropped the ring into the sea, where it was immediately swallowed by a fish.  The unlucky fish was then caught and served to Salome, where she found her special ring in the belly of the fish.  She then returned to her queendom, sought out the imposter and imprisoned her in the jail for the harm she did to her people.

[118]It is said that if Joan had recovered, she dreamt that she should strike her husband for 100 times for all the trouble he caused her.

[119]The fight arose because the robbers would not split the spoils of theft with him equally after ransacking a home.  The husband did this, even though as an exhusband, Salome continued to provide his necessaries for him out of her wealth.  One of his issues was greed.
